alert.note: Alert for Laurens (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 21 at 12:20AM EDT until June 25 at 12:31PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 AM EDT EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...A portion of upstate South Carolina, including the following county, Laurens. * WHEN...Until 200 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas, including farmland, greenways, low-water crossings, underpasses, and low-lying drainages and parking lots. High water flows over low-water crossings and low-lying roadways are possible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1215 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. - At 1215 AM EDT, a line of showers is moving up the South Carolina Upstate and training over Laurens County, reinforcing the existing flood conditions in many areas. Rain rates have lowered compared to earlier today, but antecedent conditions have worsened. Caution is advised near any stream or other vulnerable area, including flood-prone areas in the city of Laurens, including along the Little River and Little River Park. If you live near a stream or creek be prepared to seek higher ground when the water begins to rise. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Laurens, Clinton, Fountain Inn, Gray Court, Cross Hill, Waterloo, Lake Greenwood, Mountville, Ora, Hickory Tavern and Enoree. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
